questions.question:
Question 1: The newborn eye is usually  
.
questions.explanation:
A newborn is usually hypermetropic by +2D to +3D. The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the eyeball at birth is about 16.5 mm, which is about 70% of 
the adult size. This reduced axial length causes light to converge behind the retina, leading to 12 
Sold by @itachibot hypermetropia. Additionally, the corneal diameter at birth is 10 mm. The adult size (11.7 mm) is attained by 2 
years of age. The orbit is more divergent (50°) as compared to adult (45°). Note: The lacrimal glands are underdeveloped in a newborn and, hence, do not secrete tears.

questions.question: Question 2: At what age would a child attain full visual acuity?
questions.explanation:
Full visual acuity is attained by the age of 6 years. Important milestones in visual development are: • At birth, there is no central fixation, and the eyes move randomly. • By the first month of life, the fixation reflex starts developing and becomes established by 6 
months. • By 3 months, binocular vision is established. • By 6 months, macular stereopsis and accommodation reflex are fully developed. • By 6 years of age, full visual acuity (6/6) is attained.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 45-year-old lady presents with the abnormality as shown below. She is diagnosed with uveal 
melanoma. What is the embryological origin of the cells involved? 4 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Uveal melanomas arise from uveal melanocytes. Uveal and conjunctival melanocytes are derived 
from the neural crest cells.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements is false regarding the development of the eye?

options.a: The macula is fully developed at birth.
options.c: The cornea attains normal diameter by 2 years.
options.d: Full visual acuity is attained by 6 years of age.

questions.explanation:
The macula is fully developed by 4–6 months of age. Apart from the macula, the rest of the retina 
is fully developed at birth. Postnatal Development of Eye: • 3 Months - Binocular single vision develops. • 4-6 Months - Macula fully develops. Fusional reflexes, stereopsis, and accommodation become 
well developed • 6 Months - Fixation, which had started developing in the first month is now complete • 2 Years - Cornea develops to the normal adult diameter • 6 Years - Visual acuity fully develops and reaches 6/6 • The lens, however, continues to grow throughout the life 13 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: By how many weeks of embryonic development does the optic groove appear?
questions.explanation:
The optic groove appears by 3 weeks. By approximately day 22, 2 small grooves appear on either 
side of the developing forebrain in the neural folds, these are called optic grooves. As the neural 
tube closes, these grooves develop outpouchings called optic vesicles. These optic vesicles extend 
from the forebrain to the surface ectoderm.

questions.question:
Question 6: Embryonic development of ciliary muscles is from  
.
questions.explanation: Embryonic development of ciliary muscles is from the neural crest.

questions.question:
Question 7: After conception, the canal of Schlemm appears by  
 . 5 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
14 
Sold by @itachibot The canal of Schlemm appears by the 4th month after conception.

questions.question: Question 8: What is the anteroposterior diameter of the adult eyeball?
questions.explanation:
The anteroposterior (AP) diameter of the adult eye is 24 mm/2.4 cm. At birth, the average axial length of the eyeball is 16.5 mm. By 3 years, it grows rapidly to 
approximately 23 mm. From 3 to 14 years of age, the axial length gradually increases by a further 
1 mm, bringing it to the adult size of 24 mm. This overall adjustment in the eye size, including the 
refractive power, is called emmetropization.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 34-year-old lady comes to the clinic complaining of problems in her vision. On perimetry, a 
visual field defect as shown below is obtained. Which of the following vessels does not supply 
the anatomical location of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
The image shows bitemporal hemianopia, a defect caused by optic chiasmal lesions. The 
middle cerebral artery does not supply the optic chiasma. Blood supply of optic chiasma: • Anterior cerebral artery - dorsal chiasma • Anterior communicating artery - ventral chiasma • Internal carotid artery - ventral chiasma • Superior hypophyseal artery - ventral (branch of internal carotid artery).

questions.question:
Question 10: A college student comes to the OPD for refractive error testing. Her eyes are dilated using 
tropicamide. Which of the following statements is false about the structure this drug acts on?

options.a: It is triangular in cross section.
options.b: There are around 30-40 processes in pars plana and pars plicata
options.c: Its epithelium is derived from the anterior edge of the optic cup.
options.d: The pars plana is approximately 4.5 mm from the limbus.

questions.explanation:
Tropicamide is a cycloplegic drug that acts on the ciliary body to cause mydriasis for refractory 
error testing. The ciliary body is a triangular structure that contains 60-70 ciliary processes in 15 
Sold by @itachibot each eye, present on the pars plicata. The pars plana is 4.5mm from the limbus while the distance between the equator and the limbus 
is 14mm. The ciliary epithelium is derived from the optic cup (neuroectoderm) by the continued growth of 
the outer lip's anterior edge.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 12-year-old girl you examined in an outreach camp is found to have this abnormality. What 
is the most common site where the condition is seen?
questions.explanation:
The condition depicted in the image is a coloboma of the iris, and the most common site of 
coloboma is the inferonasal quadrant. A coloboma is a congenital malformation in one of the structures in the eye, such as the iris, 
retina, choroid, or optic disc, due to the failure of embryonic fissure closure. Coloboma of the 
uveal tract may be typical (seen in the inferonasal quadrant) or atypical (occasionally found in 
other positions). Typical coloboma is of two types: • Complete: Extends from pupil to optic nerve, causing a corresponding lens indentation. • Incomplete: May involve iris alone, or iris and ciliary body (more common), or iris, ciliary body 
and a part of choroid. Other embryonic remnants in the eye: • Mittendorf's dot - Remnant of the anterior end of the hyaloid artery • Bergmeister papilla - Remnant of the posterior end of the hyaloid artery • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) - Failure of fetal vasculature to regress The image below shows a fundoscopy view of persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous. 16 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: 7 
Sold by @itachibot A child was brought with complaints of decreased vision. Fundus examination shows a 
developmental anomaly as shown below. What is the cause of this anomaly?

options.a: Incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure
options.b: Faulty migration of neural crest cells

questions.explanation:
The image shows a coloboma of the optic disc, accompanied by a large chorioretinal coloboma 
located below the optic disc, which is caused by incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure. This developmental anomaly may involve the optic nerve, choroid, retina, and iris. Coloboma of 
the optic disc can present in two forms: a minor effect often associated with refractive errors like 
hypermetropia and astigmatism and a fully developed coloboma that appears as a large 
inferonasal whitish excavation resembling the optic disc. Defective vision and superior visual field defects are typically associated with fully developed 
coloboma. Additionally, this condition may be associated with chorioretinal coloboma, a 
congenital anomaly where the developing optic cup fails to fuse completely, leading to abnormal 
choroidal and retinal development. Note: Faulty migration of neural crest cells results in anterior segment dysgenesis.

questions.question:
Question 13: What is the embryological origin of the structure marked in the image? 8 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The lacrimal gland arises from the surface ectoderm. 17 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: The optic foramen is situated between the:

options.a: Lesser and greater wings of the sphenoid
options.b: Lesser wing and body of the sphenoid
options.c: Greater wing and body of the sphenoid
options.d: Two roots of the lesser wing of the sphenoid

questions.explanation:
The optic foramen is situated between the two roots of the lesser wing of the sphenoid. The optic foramen leads into the optic canal, which is formed medially by the body and laterally 
by the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, connecting the orbit's apex to the middle cranial fossa. The optic canal transmits the optic nerve with its meningeal coverings; the ophthalmic artery, 
which is below the nerve, is embedded in its dural sheath, and a few twigs from the sympathetic 
plexus accompanying the artery.

questions.question:
Question 15: During a game, a 26-year-old baseball player is hit in the head by a baseball, which fractures 
the optic canal. Which of the following pairs of structures is most likely to be damaged?
questions.explanation:
18 
Sold by @itachibot In the given clinical scenario, a fracture of the optic canal is most likely to damage the ophthalmic 
artery and optic nerve, as these are the primary structures passing through it. The optic foramen leads into the optic canal, which is a short cylindrical structure bounded 
medially by the body and laterally by the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone, connecting the orbit's 
apex to the middle cranial fossa, serving as a pathway for the aforementioned structures along 
with its sympathetic plexus. Optic canal fractures, often associated with basilar skull fractures, can lead to optic neuropathy. 
The intracanalicular and intracranial portion of the optic nerve is most commonly affected in head 
trauma. Note: The greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid bound the superior orbital fissure.

questions.question:
Question 16: The anterior segment of the eye includes all except  
.
questions.explanation:
The anterior segment of the eye does not include vitreous humor as it is a constituent of the 
posterior segment of the eye. Anterior Segment 
Posterior Segme 
nt Cornea 
Vitreous humor Iris 
Retina Lens 
Choroid Anterior and Posterior cham 
bers with aqueous humor Optic Disc

questions.question:
Question 17: The posterior chamber in the eyeball is filled with  
. 9 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
19 
Sold by @itachibot The posterior chamber of the eyeball is filled with aqueous humor. The eyeball is divided into anterior and posterior segments. The anterior segment includes the 
lens and the structures anterior to it, such as the cornea, iris and two aqueous humor-filled 
spaces: • Anterior chamber: Located between cornea and iris, contains aqueous humor and 
communicates with the posterior chamber through the pupil. • Posterior chamber: Triangular-shaped space, also contains aqueous humor, bounded anteriorly 
by the posterior surface of the iris, laterally by the ciliary body, and posteriorly by the lens. The posterior segment includes all structures located posterior to the lens, comprising of the 
vitreous humor, retina, choroid and optic disc.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following structures is attached to Whitnall’s tubercle?

options.a: Check ligament of the medial rectus
options.c: Check ligament of the lateral rectus

questions.explanation:
Check ligament of the lateral rectus is attached to Whitnall’s tubercle. Lateral orbital tubercle or Whitnall's tubercle is a small elevation on the orbital surface of the 
zygomatic bone, just within the lateral orbital margin. It is about 11 mm below the 
fronto-zygomatic suture. Four structures are attached to it: • Check ligament of the lateral rectus • Lockwood’s ligament (Suspensory ligament of the eyeball) • Lateral palpebral ligament • Lateral horn of the levator aponeurosis The Whitnall's ligament or the superior transverse ligament of the eye, is attached to the superior 
tarsal plate and the orbital bone. 20 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following statements is false regarding the tarsal plates?

options.b: They give structural support to the eyelid.
options.c: LPS aponeurosis is attached to the superior border of the upper tarsal plate.
options.d: Their medial and lateral ends form the medial and lateral palpebral ligaments, respectively.

questions.explanation:
The tarsal plates are not cartilaginous structures but firm, dense connective tissue (fibrous tissue) 
plates. The tarsal plates serve as the structural support of the eyelids. The height of the upper tarsal plate 
is about 10 mm, and that of the lower tarsal plate is 4 mm. Both plates have a thickness of about 1 
mm. The ends form the medial and lateral palpebral ligaments (medial and lateral canthal 
tendons). The levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) aponeurosis is attached to the superior border of 
the upper tarsal plate. The meibomian glands are located within the tarsus. These are holocrine-secreting sebaceous 
glands that are not associated with lash follicles. 21 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A 55-year-old man is being evaluated for herpes zoster ophthalmicus. On eliciting corneal 
reflex, there is no response. Which of the following nerves forms the afferent limb of this 
reflex?
questions.explanation:
The sensory supply of the cornea comes from the long ciliary nerve (branch of the nasociliary 
nerve). It forms the afferent limb of the corneal reflex. The sensory nerve supply of the eye is by the ophthalmic nerve. • Lacrimal nerve- lacrimal gland, conjunctiva, lateral eyelid • Frontal nerve- conjunctiva, eyelid, part of the forehead • Nasociliary nerve • Long ciliary nerve- cornea, ciliary body, iris • Infra-trochlear nerve- conjunctiva, lacrimal sac, caruncle, medial part of the eyelids Corneal sensation is reduced in leprosy and diabetes mellitus (neuropathy).

questions.question:
Question 21: Which intrinsic ocular muscle has a parasympathetic innervation? 10 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: The intrinsic ocular muscle supplied by parasympathetic innervation is the sphincter pupillae. 1. Parasympathetic innervation: • Sphincter pupillae: Short ciliary nerve–Ciliary ganglion • Ciliary muscle–Accessory ganglion 2. Sympathetic innervation: Dilator pupillae and Muller’s muscle 3. Motor Supply: • 3rd nerve: All extraocular muscles (except the 2 given below) • 6th nerve: Lateral rectus (LR6) • 4th nerve: Superior oblique (SO4) • 7th nerve: Orbicularis oculi

questions.question: Question 22: What is the thinnest part of the retina?
questions.explanation:
The retina is the thinnest (0.080 mm) at the ora serrata, and thickest, at the foveal rim (0.23, 
0.320 mm). The ora serrata is the serrated junction between the retina and ciliary body.

questions.question:
Question 23: In the anatomy dissection hall, you are shown the dissected orbit with the markers as shown 
below. You are asked to choose the muscles causing depression of the eyeball. Which will you 
choose?
questions.explanation:
22 
Sold by @itachibot The muscles responsible for the depression of the eyeball are the inferior rectus (E) and superior 
oblique (A). Image markings: • A- Superior oblique • B- Levator palpebrae superiors • C- Superior rectus • D- Inferior oblique • E- Inferior rectus Nerve supply of extra-ocular muscles: • Oculomotor nerve (III)- Superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, inferior oblique, and 
levator palpebrae superioris • Abducens nerve (VI)- Lateral rectus • Trochlear nerve (IV)- Superior oblique 23 
Sold by @itachibot Elementary Optics and Physiology of Vision
